column1: Mansfield is a market town in Nottinghamshire
column3: the main town in the District of Mansfield and Mansfield Urban Area. Mansfield gained the Royal Charter of a market town in 1227.  The town lies in the Maun Valley
column4: 12 miles (19 km) north of Nottingham
column5: and is near Sutton-in-Ashfield. Most of the 106
column6: 556 population live within the town proper (including Mansfield Woodhouse)
column7: with Market Warsop as a secondary centre. It is the only local authority in Nottinghamshire directly to elect its mayor.

column1: Settlement dates to the Roman period. Major Hayman Rooke in 1787 discovered a villa between Mansfield Woodhouse and Pleasley; a cache of denarii was found near King's Mill in 1849. Early English royalty stayed there; Mercian Kings used it as a base to hunt in Sherwood Forest.The Domesday Book (1086) recorded the settlement as Mammesfeld and market-petition documents of 1227 spelt it Maunnesfeld. King Richard II signed a warrant in November 1377 to grant tenants the right to hold a four-day fair each year; the spelling had changed to Mannesfeld. There are remains of the 12th-Century King John's Palace in Clipstone
column3: and it was an area of retreat for royal families and dignitaries through to the 15th Century. Access to the town was by road from the city of Nottingham
column4: on the way to Sheffield. In the town centre
column5: a commemorative plaque marks the point thought once to be the centre of Sherwood Forest. A tree was planted nearby but has since been felled and replaced by a sculpture.Travellers in the 16th and 17th centuries had several inns and stable yards dating from the medieval period to stop at: the Harte; the Swan
column6: with 1490 dating stone; the Talbot; the White Bear; the Ram
column7: with timber from before 1500; and the White Lion.. Several timber-framed cruck buildings were demolished in 1929; and in 1973 a local historical society documented another during demolition dated to 1400 or earlier. Other Tudor houses in Stockwell Gate
column9: and Lime Tree Place were also demolished to make way for development before they could be viewed for listing. Most remaining buildings are from the 17th century.

column1: Mansfield is a market town with a 700-year-old market tradition; a Royal Charter was issued in 1227. The present market square was created after demolition under the Improvement Act of 1823. In the centre is the Bentinck Memorial
column3: which commemorates Lord George Bentinck (1802–1848)
column4: son of the William Bentinck
column5: 4th Duke of Portland
column6: a local landowner.A nearby area called Buttercross Market in West Gate
column7: the site of an old cattle market
column8: has a centrepiece of local stone dating from the 16th century. Mansfield District Council closed this section in 2015. Adjacent is Mansfield Library
column9: officially opened by the Queen in 1977 and refurbished in 2012. The old Carnegie Library
column11: was used from 1976 as an arts and performance centre.

column1: Mansfield has a temperate oceanic climate (Köppen: Cfb)
column3: an even spread of rainfall
column4: low levels of sunshine and often breezy conditions throughout the year. The closest weather-station records for Mansfield come from Warsop in Meden Vale
column5: seven miles to the north.

column1: The absolute maximum temperature record for the area stands at 34.6 °C (94.3 °F)
column2: recorded in August 1990. In a typical year the warmest day should reach 28.9 °C (84.0 °F) and 12.72 days should reach 25.1 °C (77.2 °F) or higher.The absolute minimum temperature record for the area is −19.1 °C (−2.4 °F)
column3: recorded in January 1987. There is air frost on an average of 59 nights a year.Rainfall averages 634 mm a year
column4: with 113 days reporting in excess of 1 mm of rain (observation period 1971–2000).

column1: Mansfield has a market square surrounded by commercial premises. It also has a museum; the Palace Theatre; and many restaurants
column3: pubs
column4: bars
column5: and night clubs.

column1: Among Mansfield's retail outlets is an indoor shopping centre
column3: with over 50 units occupied by national chains and phone shops
column4: and two department stores. Other stores and a coffee chain have been in West Gate since 2011
column5: along with existing similar cafés. Rosemary Centre is a pedestrianised area off the town centre with a covered parade. There are also three outdoor retail parks
column6: two with adjacent branded fast-food outlets.

column1: The headquarters of Mansfield District Council occupied part of a former recreation ground at Chesterfield Road South from late 1986; it was opened in 1987 by Princess Anne. Catering facilities are run by outside contractors.From 2012

column4: an agency within the Department for Work and Pensions

column1: Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries in October 1999 aquired Mansfield Brewery
column2: once the United Kingdom's largest independent brewery
column3: for £253 million. Production of the Mansfield range of ales moved out and the site was later sold to Pubmaster Ltd; the site is yet to be redeveloped. In the 1980s
column4: Mansfield Bitter was advertised with a photograph of then US President Ronald Reagan and the tagline: "He might be president of the most powerful nation on earth... but he's never had a pint of Mansfield." "Not much matches Mansfield" was also used and became the title for a play set in the town written for the Mansfield Arts Festival.

column3: with brand names Sunecta and Mandora
column4: was bought by Mansfield Brewery in 1977. A move to a modern factory in Bellamy Road in 1975 released land projected for a high-density housing development known as Layton Burroughs. Mansfield Brewery sold the business in 1988 for £21.5 million to the Scottish drinks company A. G. Barr plc
column5: producer of Irn-Bru
column6: Tizer
column7: and Mandora. At the time the firm employed 400 people. Production ceased there in January 2011 when A. G. Barr closed the factory and production to other sites. Despite demolition of the brewery production buildings in 2008
column9: the site remained unsold. The older ornate offices now house a learning centre.

column1: Many areas near the town and in surrounding countryside still show signs of coal mining
column2: the main industry for most of the 20th century. A violent episode in the UK miners' strike (1984–1985) occurred in Mansfield on May Day 1984. Most the area's miners had voted against a strike
column3: but the local union initially maintained that the strike was official to show solidarity with strikers in other areas. When the coal board granted an extra day of leave after the bank holiday
column4: a group of working miners confronted union officials and violence broke out with striking miners. Mansfield later hosted a breakaway union
column5: the Union of Democratic Mineworkers
column6: which recruited many who had opposed the 1984–1985 strike. The head stocks close to the village of Clipstone are an important local landmark and community groups are trying to preserve them as a reminder of the area's mining history. As demand for coal fell
column7: Mansfield's pits wound down and miners had to find other work.

column1: Mining subsidence causes problems for properties around Mansfield. A few streets in and around the town form long rows of terraced houses reminiscent of the affordable housing provided for mine workers in the prime of the industry. Many were demolished in 2012 in Pleasley Hill
column2: Market Warsop and elsewhere. The Coal Authority is based in the town.

column1: In 2019 the UK government set up the Towns Fund
column2: which aimed to regenerate areas in need of regeneration. Mansfield was one of these places with the aim of receiving 25 million for its regeneration and development. This is to part with The Mansfield Townscape Heritage Project
column3: which provided grants by the National Lottery to renovate parts of the town centre.

column1: Several urban regeneration projects planned for Mansfield involved large-scale demolition
column2: but the financial crisis of 2007–2008 and subsequent central-government funding cuts and escalating austerity measures deferred them. Mansfield District Council promoted two new developments: Arrival Square
column3: opened 2008
column4: an office block occupied by the Probation Service by the rail station; and Queen's Place—completed and opened by the mayor
column5: Tony Egginton
column6: in late 2013—which cost the council £2.4 million. It offered two new ground-floor retail units and six offices in Queen Street between the new transport interchange and the market square.Reconstruction of nearby King's Mill Hospital in Sutton in Ashfield was completed in 2009. It is near the Mansfield and Ashfield Regeneration Route
column7: which opened in 2004 as a bypass designed to reduce through traffic and improve access by connecting the A617 at Pleasley to the A617 at Rainworth.In 2009 Mansfield made a bid for city status
column9: residential and leisure facilities with road improvements gradually being made; still pending as of August 2020.

column1: Mansfield railway station is on the Robin Hood Line
column2: a link connecting with Nottingham and Worksop. From 1964 until the line reopened in 1995
column3: Mansfield was by some definitions the largest town in Britain without a railway station
column4: remarkable after the town had pioneered the railway in the East Midlands. From 1973 to 1995 the nearby station at Alfreton was named "Alfreton and Mansfield Parkway" to encourage use as a railhead for Mansfield. A Sunday rail service was restored to Mansfield in December 2008.

column1: The town was originally the terminus of the Mansfield and Pinxton Railway
column2: a horse-drawn plateway built in 1819 and one of the first acquisitions of the newly formed Midland Railway. The Midland used the final section to extend its new Leen Valley line to the present station in 1849.

column1: The Midland Railway extended its Rolleston Junction–Southwell branch to Mansfield in 1871; continued the line north to Worksop in 1875; opened a link from Mansfield Woodhouse to Westhouses and Blackwell in 1886; and completed another link from Pleasley through Bolsover to Barrow Hill in 1890. The locally promoted Mansfield Railway between Kirkby South Junction and Clipstone Junctions—opened in stages between 1913 and 1916 for goods trains and in 1917 for Nottingham–Ollerton passenger trains
column2: calling at a second Mansfield passenger station—broke the Midland Railway monopoly. Though nominally independent
column3: the Mansfield Railway connected at both ends with the Great Central Railway
column4: which worked the trains.Mansfield had two railway stations: Mansfield Town
column5: the former Midland station on Station Road; and Mansfield Central
column6: the former Mansfield Railway station in Great Central Road
column7: near Ratcliffe Gate. Central station lost its scheduled passenger services at the beginning of 1956 and Town station closed to passengers in 1964
column8: leaving Mansfield without passenger trains until the Robin Hood line restored them in 1995.

column1: Mansfield & District Light Railways ran a tram service between 1905 and 1932.
Buses in Mansfield are mainly operated by Stagecoach
column2: with Trent Barton and National Express also working the area. The council granted planning permission for a new bus station on the former Station Road car park
column3: expected to cost £7 million
column4: in 2006. The old bus station
column5: built in 1977
column6: handled around 1
column8: 000 passenger arrivals a day; but had an outdated design and appearance

column1: There were good pedestrian links to the pedestrianised town-centre shopping streets; however
column2: the railway station was several hundred yards away. The new bus station addressed the problem but proved unpopular with shopkeepers near the old facility
column3: with several claiming marked reductions in trade.The new bus station and transport interchange opened on 31 March 2013 in a location on a former car park close to the railway station. It is part of a regeneration scheme known as "Gateway To Mansfield"
column4: which aims to give visitors a clean and tidy first impression
column5: including buildings with a themed use of local sandstone. The scheme also aims to improve facilities for locals
column6: boost visitors to the town and help step up the local economy.

column1: The new bus station increased passenger safety and provides a more welcoming scene for arriving visitors. Improvements have included an enclosed waiting area
column2: automatic doors for fume reduction and safety
column3: a tourist information centre
column4: electronic bus and rail departure information
column5: toilets
column6: and baby-changing facilities. A tower with lift and stairs to an elevated walkway connects it to the railway station.

column1: Mansfield is home to Mansfield Town FC
column2: known as the Stags or yellows. Relegated to the Conference National after 77 years in the Football League at the end of the 2007–2008 season
column3: Mansfield Town returned to the Football League after winning the 2012–2013 Conference National title. Non-League club AFC Mansfield plays in the Forest Town area of Mansfield.

column1: Mansfield Rugby Club is a rugby union club based at Eakring Road and currently plays in Midlands 1 East
column2: a sixth-tier league in the English rugby union system. It won the Notts Cup for five years in succession and for a record 18 times.

column1: Mansfield Giants is Mansfield's Premier Basketball Club
column2: and has a three-star Accreditation and Club Mark from the English Sports Council. The team plays in the England Basketball (EB2).

column1: The annual half marathon held for more than 30 years was cancelled after 2011 due to escalating costs
column2: after changes to Health and Safety legislation meant professional services were needed to address road-closure measures
column3: instead of volunteers. Mansfield local business networking group 2020 had hoped to restore a race by September 2014
column4: but this event
column5: reduced in length to 10 kilometres
column6: was postponed
column8: and took place in August.Angling is well supported in the Mansfield district
column9: where ponds remain from the former textile milling industry.

column1: Tennis is catered for by Mansfield Lawn Tennis Club located at the same site since 1883
column2: with two grass courts and four asphalt courts
column3: three of them floodlit. Further hard-surface courts are found in the district at six Mansfield District Council park locations.Mansfield is home to Mansfield Roller Derby
column4: Mansfield's premier Flat Track Roller Derby league.One issue for local residents is Mansfield's lack of a central Leisure Centre. Mansfield District Council decided it would rubber stamp the sale of the existing Leisure Centre and extensive public car park to Tesco
column5: which opened a large Tesco Extra store in 2007. The Council asserted that this would be replaced by a brand new Leisure Centre
column6: but nothing has been built or is planned. It received over £5m from Tesco for the Leisure Centre site
column7: but decided to spend this on refurbishing Sherwood Baths instead.Mansfield has two indoor swimming centres and a third
column8: smaller pool attached to a school
column9: which has been under threat of closure since 2011. These facilities give Mansfield the largest square meterage of indoor water-sports facilities per capita of any town in the United Kingdom with less than 100

column1: Mansfield is one of three outlets for the Nottinghamshire County Council Swim Squad
column2: which competes as Nova Centurion. The Sherwood Swimming Baths adjacent to the former Sherwood Colliery was refurbished and opened in January 2010 as the Rebecca Adlington Swimming Centre. The 25-metre pool was widened at the expense of losing tiered public seating and has a new
column3: small
column4: endless stroke-improvement training pool with variable-resistance water flow. The complex reduces its carbon footprint by using a ground-source heat pump backed by a biomass boiler burning wood pellets prepared from waste by a local wood yard.At the Beijing 2008 Olympic Games
column5: a Mansfield contestant
column6: Rebecca Adlington
column8: for 400 and 800-metre freestyle swimming. After her record-breaking success
column9: Adlington was welcomed home to Mansfield by thousands lining the streets to applaud as she passed in an open top bus. This culminated in an appearance at the old Town Hall in the Market Square. Her success boosted swimming interest in the area
column10: leading to expansion of swimming classes to encourage young people to begin swimming. At the 2012 Olympic Games in and around London
column11: Adlington won two Bronze medals again for 400 and 800 metres
column12: the best performance of a generally disappointing Team GB swimming squad. She retired from competitive swimming in February 2012.Water Meadows swimming complex opened during the Christmas holidays of 1990 in Bath Street
column13: on the site of the former Mansfield Baths and defunct cattle market. It has a gym and a soft-play area for children with an adjoining café
column14: as well as one 25-metre competition pool
column16: and a small teaching pool. The leisure lagoon pool has an artificial wave machine operating periodically
column17: and also a slide and a shallow area like a beach. The complex is popular with family groups
column18: and many surrounding schools make use of its facilities.

column1: The main cemetery and crematorium occupy a 10-acre site accessed from Derby Road
column2: on the southern edge of town near to the boundary with Ashfield. They share a car park. In late 2015
column3: Mansfield District Council recognised the need for additional spaces and planning consent was obtained. The older part of the cemetery
column4: fronting Nottingham Road and Forest Hill (the old Derby Road) has on-street parking. Site access on foot can be hard due to the steep slope.The cemetery was opened in 1857 due to insufficient church graveyard space
column5: the mid-to-late Victorian population growth and several then-new churches built with little or no dedicated graveyard areas. A 10-acre extension was made in 1898. The adjacent Mansfield and District Crematorium
column6: with two chapels seating 35 and up to 80
column7: was set up in 1960. and is a responsibility shared between Mansfield District Council
column8: Ashfield District Council and Newark and Sherwood District Council.There are other cemeteries on the A60 at Mansfield Woodhouse and at Warsop
column9: and off the A617 at Pleasley Hill.

column1: The Palace Theatre in Leeming St is the town's prime entertainment venue. Built as a cinema in 1910 and originally known as the Palace Electric Theatre
column2: it was adapted as a theatre with a proscenium arch
column3: presenting live shows. It was known as the Civic Hall and Civic Theatre before the current name was revived in 1995. With a seating capacity of 534
column4: the theatre is a mid-scale touring venue. It presents a programme of professional and amateur productions and a yearly pantomime.Mansfield Museum
column5: beside the Palace Theatre in Leeming Street
column6: opened in 1904. and has been based on its present site since 1938. With free entry
column7: it won the Guardian Family-friendly Museum of the Year Award in 2011.Mansfield was home to Venue 44
column8: a nightclub that gave birth to the superclub Renaissance which was operated there in 1992–1994 by Geoff Oakes and launched the DJ's Sasha
column10: Nigel Dawson and Ian Ossia to global fame. The building was demolished in 2010.

column1: The Old Library near the town centre houses a recording studio

column1: A few miles outside Mansfield lies Sherwood Forest. Mansfield had an oak tree and a plaque in West Gate to mark what was the centre of Sherwood Forest. Now the tree has been felled and a giant metallic feather has replaced it as a marker. Some residents of the town feel this is an eyesore
column2: and the feather sculpture has been plagued by health and safety problems.

column1: Every year between June and August
column2: Mansfield District Council hosts a Summer in the Streets festival. This consists of various public events held all across the town over many days
column3: such as children's entertainment
column4: fairground rides in the market square
column5: and hands-on workshops for things like crafts and circus skills.

column1: The festival highlight is a final event in Titchfield Park called Party in the Park. Its range of entertainment includes live music acts by local bands
column3: and activities such as face painting. For 2012 and 2013
column4: this culminating event was cancelled for austerity reasons.On 21 August 2010 the various summer entertainment arranged by Mansfield District Council included the Irish boy band Westlife in a live concert at Field Mill stadium
column5: home to the town's football team
column6: the Stags. This was the first big-name act to visit the town.

column1: The local newspapers are the Chad (formerly Chronicle Advertiser) and Mansfield and Ashfield News Journal

column1: Television reception in Mansfield is often poor due to its location between regions. Historically

column1: Mansfield receives its television signals from various transmitters: Waltham from East Midlands

column1: Mansfield has a directly elected mayor
column2: as one of only 16 places with one in the United Kingdom. Tony Egginton was Mayor of Mansfield from October 2002 until retirement in May 2015
column3: being replaced at scheduled elections by a fellow candidate for the Mansfield Independent Forum political party
column4: Kate Allsop. Much was said of the first Executive Mayor
column5: but during his time in office
column6: Mansfield struggled with local land development and many projects across the region faltered.The Mayor (in office 2002–2015) was criticised by some councillors and residents for placing too much focus on self-publicity
column7: as opposed to publicity for the town. The issue was raised again after his prominent role in Olympic swimmer Rebecca Adlington's homecoming ceremony
column8: after her Gold Medal successes at the 2008 Beijing Olympic games.In April 2017
column9: Sophie Whitby was elected to the Mansfield district as a Member of Youth Parliament
column10: on a manifesto that included promoting equality for the LGBT community.Benjamin Bradley has been the constituency (Conservative) Member of Parliament since May 2017
column12: who served the town for 30 years.

husband and wife Christopher and Susan Edwards were jailed for murdering the woman's parents

column4: whose bodies lay undiscovered in their back garden for 15 years. The couple had stolen thousands of pounds
column5: siphoned off the Wycherleys' pensions and sold their house

column11: had written Christmas cards and letters to relatives telling them her parents were travelling in Ireland "because of the good air" and told neighbours they were in Blackpool or Morecambe. The Edwards were sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum of 25 years for the murders
column12: concurrent with 9-year sentences for disposing of the bodies and theft.On 30 May 2015
